job_title: Director of Career Services in Houston, TX
pros: In my six months there, the best day I had was serving hot dogs to students as a morale booster. Everything else was awful.
cons: I’ve been working near constantly since I was 16. About 20 years. I’ve had a few jobs that I wouldn’t choose to go back to, but most were good. The one job you couldn’t offer me enough money in the world to return to is Career Services at Remington. I’ve never woken up sick to my stomach in the morning for any other job. The president walked in every morning to look me over and see what I was wearing - always professional, always the right length, always appropriate. But every morning, I was given the once over. So was my team. The phones are bugged; meetings are listened in on. Reviews with the regional president are nightmarish. He tells you how to prepare then does the opposite of what he says he will do. He sat in the back of a dark room and degraded my team, my progress, everything I did while I had to look ahead and was advised not to turn around to speak to him. I was told what colors to wear on those review days. I was told not to wear lotion or perfume or too much jewelry because it “offended him”. While being spoken to like an idiot, I was told to just sit there and listen and never talk back. What kind of workplace is that? As for the work scope - it’s impossible. If 100 kids graduate, you’re expected to place 100 kids in jobs. If you place 99, they ask why you didn’t place 100. The problem was places wouldn’t hire Remington students because the education they get isn’t good enough to get them hired. While cold calling to try and place students in jobs, employers would ask what school I was calling from. When I told them Remington, sometimes they would say “we don’t hire Remington students”. Sometimes they would just hang up. If the regional career services director is feeling pressured enough, they’ll tell you to fudge the numbers - and they’re ALWAYS feeling pressured. Remington is an awful diploma mill and every location should be forced to shut its doors. Please avoid it. You won’t last long anyway - they don’t keep anyone long. When they do let you go, they’ll make you sign a document that states that nothing unethical is happening at Remington and that you never witnesses anything that could be deemed unethical. Trust me, though, you will. Every day.

pros: None. Some co-workers were wonderful people but everyone just tried to keep their head down, terrified that the next bad business decision made by upper management will negatively affect them.

review_title: You are where and who you work for.  If you don't believe this keep looking elsewhere, I am!

Location
Payment is on time
There is no visible HR, this is all done electronically.
Generally you report to one person and they report to one or two people

cons: Location.  The schools are located in areas of poverty, thus the employees tend to not have a levelo of professionalism because those ired live or have lived in the area and know someone at the school, hence why they were hired.  I knew no one prior to being hired, so i was the "difference to this standard".  Everything here is perception based.  Students perceive this school as caring, teachers provide their cell hone, managers call you, all to make you FEEL important, but it is perception.  EVERYONES job is on the line 24/7 so it is a requirement not an option.  Staff turnover in the last 6 months was a loss of 35 employees, the longest tenure is at about 3 -5 years.  Students enroll in the school due to lack of knowledge about other better viable college options OR because they are scared, need a carrer and need one fast.  Sadly this is why the employers work here.  When you are desperate desperation will be the ruin of you.

pros: I worked with some wonderful people who made going to work each day a pleasure. Also, seeing students that I had enrolled succeeding and sincerely enjoying their experience at Remington made me feel like I was making a difference.
cons:
Working as an Admissions Rep means meeting student enrollment numbers every 3-6 months.  If you miss your number on a review, you can be fired immediately.  Regardless of whether you've been there a year or twenty, your job is always on the line. 

One might think that if the entire team is struggling to make enrollment numbers, perhaps the numbers aren't realistic or there are too many people holding the same position.  I didn't make my numbers and was let go. A short while after I left, 2 more reps were laid off (both worked there for less than 9 months.  Not long after that, Remington let go of all 3 of their Financial Aid Reps. Now they're letting go of their ReEnrollment Coordinator(another type of admissions rep).  This person was with the company for years and bent over backwards to take on extra tasks and help the campus whenever possible. 

While this campus wasn't horrible to work at, there is an extremely high turnover in ALL positions and loyalty & hard work are clearly not taken into account toward job security.  It's a good job if you aren't looking for anything long term. Otherwise, you shouldn't waste your valuable time trying to cling to a job at this location.

review_title: True Life: I worked in Career Services
pros:
-Pay wasn't bad but it truly was not enough to cover the time, extreme stress, and belittling 
-Most of your co-workers feel slighted and angry too, so you are in good company because at least everyone else feels the way you do
cons:
-As the majority of other reviews have stated, Remington is many things but fair, moral, and honest are NOT any of those things. They are a diploma mill. 
-Campuses are beginning to close because their ways are catching up with them and they can't enroll enough students anymore. In a few years they won't exist anymore. 
-Career Services is a very dishonest piece of this company, though all departments are dishonest. Once students graduate, they are shuffled into career services so that you can look for a job for them. You have to move fast. They want students to get jobs as soon as possible. Once they get a job it counts toward (VERY unrealistic) numbers that career services needs to reach as part of the accreditation requirements for the school as a whole. It all sounds helpful and nice but here is the truth: they only need to hold the job for two days for it to count for Remington's numbers. If they worked there for two days and then got fired but come back to you for help looking for a job they get put on the back burner because they already got you your credit. You don't have to help them again. So, Career Services gets them into some job somewhere that is somewhat relevant to their training (I was literally told to: "find something that kind of works, we can make the job description sound like it matches their major later" ) and then hopes they make it two days (which might not happen once the people who hired them see that they were hardly trained at Remington) and then you cut them loose. 
-Remington enrolls anyone who walks through the door. Literally...anyone. Then, if they can't get decent enough grades, teachers are told to flub them so that they can pass. Teachers are also told to keep students happy no matter what they want because "happy students stay enrolled." 
-They bug all phones, they send in company hired "spies" to ask you weird questions and make sure you are saying everything the right way because they have to cover their lies up so fiercely and if you slip up and mention any of their dishonest practices, you're fired real quick.
Seriously, stay away from this place. You won't last long because they hire and fire fast.

Worst part about that is that they allowed me to relocate from one city where I worked for the company to another without mentioning that within a few months I would be out of a job in a new city.
The stress of any job in the company is unimaginable. They also find ways to get out of paying you for extra time you put in. For example, we were told we had Christmas eve off which had not ever happened. Then they said we would have to use our own paid time off to cover that day. Look elsewhere if you want to work for a school.Try to steer clear of "career colleges" . The outlook is poor because they are running out of kids to lie to and enroll. They are not honest people and a company that asks you to lie for them will also lie to you.
